header.title: Paitisha: The Book of the Serpent Draconian and Persian Sorcery
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Draconian Magic, Persian Sorcery, Left Hand Path

central_thesis: Paitisha outlines a modern Luciferian Left Hand Path system rooted in an inverted Zoroastrian demonology and Persian sorcery. It emphasizes radical self-deification, individual will, and the mastery of both darkness and light through the invocation and integration of adversarial forces like Ahriman/Shaitan and the Daevas/Druj, culminating in the practitioner's transformation into a 'Dragon-man' or 'Dragon-woman' embodying primal chaos and self-illumination.

structure_content.summary: This section introduces the Luciferian and Left Hand Path as a journey of individuality and self-mastery, emphasizing a balanced development of 'darker' and 'lighter' aspects. It details Shaitan's mythological origin as the first angel composed of flame who refused to prostrate before Adam, embodying awakened self-awareness and seeking more. The text connects Azrael, Azazel, and Shaitan. It explains Yatukan Sorcery and Yatuk Dinoih as modern systems drawing from inverted Zoroastrian concepts, where Paitisha signifies opposition to natural order and a self-determined focus on sorcery, aligning the practitioner with the Mind/Imagination of Ahriman.

Chaos is presented as an essential, non-directed energy holding potential for both order and initiation. The sorcerer, through instinctual magick, becomes 'Hesham' – the darkness or shadow self (Ahriman) – initiating mental isolation from the natural order. It is about mastering this chaotic force, akin to the Egyptian Set mastering Apepe, to drive internal and external growth. This chapter also briefly highlights the sigil-drawing of Sarvar as a 'gate' to Arezura.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Arish: A Tract on Persian Sorcery
structure_content.summary: This section provides a mythological narrative of creation within the Paitisha cosmology. It describes Zurvan (infinite time) and the emergence of Arimanius (Ahriman) from the womb, who, by strength of Will, was recognized as first-born. Az-Jeh, or Lilith, is introduced as Az (blackness), the dragon-bride of Ahriman, who awakens him and instructs the Daevas in procreation. Shaitan, in serpent form, offers the Black Flame of knowledge to humanity, leading to the birth of Cain through the union of Arimanius/Samael and Eve.

This ritual focuses on summoning and controlling earth forces, visualizing a beast within a ritual circle defined by Ahrimanic letters. It’s an invocation for the practitioner to integrate and manifest the Prince of Darkness, fostering empowerment rather than surrender. It includes specific incantations like 'Zazasta Unozono' and invocations to various Daevas (Angra Mainyu, Andar, Savar, Akatasha, Naunghaithya, Zairich, Taprev, Buiti, Kasvi, Aeshma) and Druj, culminating in the invocation of Paitisha and envisioning darkness forming into a great beast.

structure_content.chapter_title: Azhish: The Adversarial Dragon Rite of Zohak
structure_content.summary: The Azhish ritual serves as a rite of passage and dedication to Persian Sorcery, drawing from the legend of Zohak (Azi Dahaka) and his transformation. It involves an initiatory process where twin black serpents (representing wisdom, illuminated mind, Samael, Lilith) emerge from the practitioner's shoulders, coiling around the spine to transform the dreaming body. The rite aims for self-deification, molding one's 'Ka' or shadow form into a dragon, embodying the Ahrimanaean path ascended. It emphasizes irreversible transformation and mastery over the summoned forces.

This chapter lists various 'Staotas' or power words, serving as mantric phrases for specific magical operations. These include 'Akaurasta' for shadow manifestation, 'Estumarzanaz' and 'Nastumarzaz' for manifesting will, 'Vagastarum' for carrying desires, 'Azkzokaham' for influencing others, 'Azksernuis' for expanding one's darkness, 'Lilzumnaka' for dream-work with Lilith, 'Okmanosho' for strengthening spells, and 'Zazasta Unozono' for summoning serpents and Daevas to manifest desire.

key_concepts.definition: The Angel of Death, often associated with Azazel, who is identified with Shaitan the Adversary.
A path focused on individuality and seeking 'Light' through spiritual disunion, integrating Godforms like Shaitan, Lilith, and Cain, and mastering both darkness and light within oneself.
A philosophical and magical current emphasizing individual autonomy, self-deification, and transcending conventional morality and cosmic order for personal spiritual evolution.

Originally Azazel in the Koran, the first angel of flame who refused to prostrate before Adam out of pride, representing awakened self-being and the Adversary, synonymous with Ahriman in this context.
Identified with Shaitan, the first Angel who bore the original Fire and whose gift to humanity created life and spawned death through friction with Zurvan's light.
A modern magical current founded on ancient Persian sorcery, reinterpreting and inverting Zoroastrian demonology (Daevas and Druj) for antinomian initiatory practices.

An Avestan-Zoroastrian term meaning 'opposition, counter-action, and moving against the natural order.' It symbolizes a self-determined, antinomian dedication to sorcery, personifying Ahriman and the People of the Lie.
Zoroastrian demons or spirits, invoked and controlled by the sorcerer in Yatukan Sorcery to facilitate a 'metamorphosis in the psyche' and manifest desires.

The 'Mind/Imagination' that manifests as the prince of darkness within the sorcerer; a stronger spirit due to intellect and self-motivation, the source of the original Light from which Daevas and Druj were created, and connected to Shaitan.
The result of the Will of the source of darkness (Angra Mainyu/Ahriman), manifesting as the prince of darkness within the sorcerer, aligned with the willed direction of Paitisha.
The 'hell' or 'place in the North' in Persian mythology, conceptualized as the gates to the abysmal depths of the subconscious, and a dwelling place for Daevas.

A ritual circle, often surrounded by flour (Zisurru), symbolizing ancient Persian and Sumerian concepts of Tiamat/Azhdeha as the primal force of Chaos, which the sorcerer seeks to control for self-illumination.

Created by Zurvan as Ahriman's bride, initially 'blackness' and a 'dragon still.' She awakens Ahriman with a kiss and instructs the Daevas in procreation, becoming the Great Harlot and Vampyre Queen, identified with Lilith in Hebrew tradition.

A Persian king who, through Ahrimanic sorcery, transformed into the storm daeva Azi Dahaka, symbolizing internal transformation and the integration of wisdom and power, represented by black serpents emerging from his shoulders.

Symbolize wisdom, the power of the illuminated mind, and sexually, Samael and Lilith, whose union creates Baphomet. In Azhish, they coil about the spine, ascending to transform the dreaming body, representing irreversible initiation.
Specific power words or mantric phrases, referred to as 'Shadow Tongue,' used for summoning, manifesting desires, influencing, and strengthening magical operations within the Paitisha system.

practical_system.description: The practical system of Paitisha is centered on invocatory and evocatory rituals designed to integrate adversarial forces (Ahriman, Daevas, Druj, Az/Lilith) into the practitioner's psyche and physical being. It emphasizes intense visualization, the vibration of specific 'Staotas' (power words), and active self-transformation. The goal is to become a 'Dragon-man/woman,' embodying the Luciferian light and mastering chaos through dedicated practice, seeking knowledge, and asserting Will-Desire-Belief to manifest desires. The path is presented as irreversible, leading to a deified state.
tools: Circle of the Ahrimanic Beast (a ritual diagram or sigil, representing Tiamat/Azhdeha as Chaos).
Flour ('Zisurru') for demarcating and surrounding the ritual circle.
Sigil-drawing of Sarvar (for focus and inner communion).
Triangle of Invocation (implied for summoning Daevas, particularly Saurva).
Practitioner's Mind and Imagination (essential for visualization, embodying archetypes, and directing magical energy).
Will-Desire-Belief (the fundamental operative principle for manifesting intentions and achieving self-transformation).
rituals: The Ahrimanic Dragon-Beast Ritual (summoning and controlling Daevas/Druj within a circle, inviting possession by the Prince of Darkness, culminating in practitioner's empowerment as Ahriman made real).
Recitation of 'Zazasta Unozono' (nine times for summoning Daevas and Druj from Arezura).
Recitation of 'Arimznusta' (three times, visualizing darkness forming a great beast).
Vibration of 'Izzadrana' (nine times, for imaginative or physical entry into the circle).
Savar Invocation (summoning the leader of demons, Saurva, for antinomian dissent and self-possibility, integrating his spirit for initiatic direction).

Azhish: The Rite of Zohak (a dedication rite invoking Azi Dahaka, personified darkness, and various Daevas; focuses on the emergence of Blackened Serpents from the spine to transform the dreaming body, leading to becoming a Dragon-man/woman).
Vibration of Staotas of Summoning (e.g., 'Arimznusta') to call specific forces and manifest psychological changes.
Invocation 'Envenom me with thy Kiss Ahriman, Akaurasta' (for physical and spiritual transformation through Ahriman's essence, leading to serpents emerging from shoulders).

Application of Staotas – Shadow Tongue (specific power words like Akaurasta, Estumarzanaz, Vagastarum, Azkzokaham, Azksernuis, Lilzumnaka, Okmanosho for various magical effects like shadow growth, will manifestation, mind control, dream manipulation, spell strengthening, and darkness expansion).

relevant_quotes.text: Life as with initiation moves in a wheel flowing against time itself. This process cannot be overlooked or cheated; Azrael's embrace is always at hand for every person. The wheel continues to turn according to time, do not waste another minute! Seek those mysteries if they speak in your blood; seek the Crooked Serpent who moves the wheel counter clockwise, invoke the Gods as they speak through your dreams; though invocation do you become them and they become you.

The aim of the initiate of the Left Hand Path is not to seek death, nor assist in the destruction of others, it is rather a misunderstood path of those who seek to become something better than their present state by the focus of Will - Desire - Belief.

Paitisha is an Avestan - Zoroastrian term which means opposition, counter-action and moving against the natural order... This self-determined focus to the practice of sorcery. This ritual working announces the sorcerer summoning and controlling the deific power of the Daeva and Druj, a seeming metamorphosis in the psyche.

The Circle of the Ahrimanic Beast should be placed in the circle and then surrounded in flour - called Zisurru in Sumerian. The Zisurru and the Circle of the Ahrimanic Beast is from the symbolism of ancient Persia and older - yet brought forth in a new flesh to the modern Left Hand Path practitioner. The image of Tiamat/Azhdeha is the primal force of Chaos, which the sorcerer seeks to control within and without his/her own being, that they ride the Dragon of Darkness to the path of self-illumination in Luciferian Light.
This ritual is not the surrendering of the individual being, rather the empowerment and encircling of it - Ahriman being a fleshed out deific power made real by the Yatuvidah his/herself.

It is the rite of encircling the Blackened Serpents from each circle, that they may coil about the spine, to ascend through the flesh and mutate your dreaming body. Will your flesh according to what you so desire. This is indeed the path of dissent against what is outwardly not of your spirit, or the intent of your being. The sorcerer now becomes the Dragon-man or Dragon-woman in flesh, the Ahrimanaean path ascended.
Deny that which you have irreversibly called, and it shall haunt your ever lasting days and nights.

critical_analysis.relevance: Paitisha is highly relevant to contemporary Left Hand Path and Luciferian currents, particularly those exploring Draconian and adversarial magic outside traditional Western Qabalah or Hermeticism. It offers a unique synthesis of Persian demonology (Ahriman, Daevas, Druj) with modern occult principles of self-deification, psychological shadow integration, and Chaos Magic (Will-Desire-Belief). The text challenges conventional interpretations of Zoroastrianism by inverting its cosmology for antinomian initiatory purposes, providing a framework for personal evolution through the mastery of 'Chaos' and adversarial archetypes.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience for Paitisha includes advanced practitioners of Left Hand Path magic, Luciferians, and adherents of the Draconian current. It appeals to sorcerers interested in Persian/Zoroastrian demonology and those seeking profound initiatory rites focused on self-transformation, empowerment, and the integration of adversarial forces. The work assumes a foundational understanding of occult concepts and a willingness to engage with challenging, antinomian, and potentially psychologically intense practices.
